articles.headline: Beyond TikTok, Walmart Looks to Transform
articles.snippet: Away from the political drama of the TikTok deal, Walmart has been taking steps that are already changing the company and, by extension, the broader retail sector.
articles.abstract: Away from the political drama of the TikTok deal, Walmart has been taking steps that are already changing the company and, by extension, the broader retail sector.
articles.lead_paragraph: Walmart’s planned investment in TikTok is being called “transformative.” Another analyst predicted the deal could “redefine retail” across the industry. “It is a bigger-picture opportunity,” said Oliver Chen, a retail analyst at Cowen.

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Urges Congress to Limit Tech’s Legal Shield
articles.snippet: President Trump and his allies have made criticism of major tech platforms a regular talking point as he campaigns for re-election.
articles.abstract: President Trump and his allies have made criticism of major tech platforms a regular talking point as he campaigns for re-election.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department sent Congress draft legislation on Wednesday that would reduce a legal shield for platforms like Facebook and YouTube, in the latest effort by the Trump administration to revisit the law as the president claims those companies are slanted against conservative voices.

articles.headline: Arthur Sulzberger Jr. to Retire as New York Times Company Chairman
articles.snippet: A changing of the guard is complete as he steps back from the board of the news organization he led to 61 Pulitzer Prizes.
articles.abstract: A changing of the guard is complete as he steps back from the board of the news organization he led to 61 Pulitzer Prizes.
articles.lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company announced on Wednesday that Arthur O. Sulzberger Jr. will retire as the chairman and as an active member of its board of directors on Dec. 31, completing a generational shift at a newspaper that has been in the same family for more than 120 years. He will be succeeded as the board’s chairman by his son, A. G. Sulzberger, the publisher.

articles.headline: Fired Officer Is Indicted in Breonna Taylor Case; Protesters Wanted Stronger Charges
articles.snippet: A former officer was charged with “wanton endangerment” for endangering Ms. Taylor’s neighbors with gunshots when she was killed by police officers in her Louisville apartment.
articles.abstract: A former officer was charged with “wanton endangerment” for endangering Ms. Taylor’s neighbors with gunshots when she was killed by police officers in her Louisville apartment.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Breonna Taylor decision and Louisville protests updates.]
articles.byline: By Rukmini Callimachi, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, John Eligon and Will Wright

articles.headline: Ginsburg Remembered as Champion of Justice as Struggle Continues Over Her Successor
articles.snippet: Long lines of mourners waited outside the Supreme Court to pay their respects, but President Trump again made clear he would not honor her dying wish that filling her seat wait until the next president was chosen.
articles.abstract: Long lines of mourners waited outside the Supreme Court to pay their respects, but President Trump again made clear he would not honor her dying wish that filling her seat wait until the next president was chosen.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — They came from far and near on a bright, warm, early autumn day, the powerful and the powerless, filled with appreciation and anxiety, to pay tribute to the daughter of a Brooklyn bookkeeper who changed the law of the land so that future generations would not have to face the obstacles that she overcame.

articles.headline: Trump Faces Challenges Even in Red States, Poll Shows, as Women Favor Biden
articles.snippet: Close races in Georgia, Iowa and Texas show President Trump’s vulnerability and suggest that Joseph Biden has assembled a formidable coalition, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll.
articles.abstract: Close races in Georgia, Iowa and Texas show President Trump’s vulnerability and suggest that Joseph Biden has assembled a formidable coalition, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump is on the defensive in three red states he carried in 2016, narrowly trailing Joseph R. Biden Jr. in Iowa and battling to stay ahead of him in Georgia and Texas, as Mr. Trump continues to face a wall of opposition from women that has also endangered his party’s control of the Senate, according to a poll conducted by The New York Times and Siena College.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: As Virus Cases Surge in Europe, Hospitalizations Lag. But for How Long?
articles.snippet: For now, countries are betting they can suppress hospital admissions and deaths without imposing more lockdowns, even as case numbers approach peak levels from last spring.
articles.abstract: For now, countries are betting they can suppress hospital admissions and deaths without imposing more lockdowns, even as case numbers approach peak levels from last spring.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In Munich, normally brimming with boisterous crowds for Oktoberfest this month, the authorities just banned gatherings of more than five people. In Marseille, France, all bars and restaurants will be closed next Monday. And in London, where the government spent weeks urging workers to return to the city’s empty skyscrapers, it is now asking them to work from home.

articles.headline: To Fight Apple and Google, Smaller App Rivals Organize a Coalition
articles.snippet: Spotify, Match Group, Epic Games and others have created a nonprofit alliance that they hope will amplify a protest against the power of the giants.
articles.abstract: Spotify, Match Group, Epic Games and others have created a nonprofit alliance that they hope will amplify a protest against the power of the giants.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For months, complaints from tech companies against Apple’s and Google’s power have grown louder.

articles.headline: Why the U.S. Risks Repeating 2009’s Economic Stimulus Mistakes
articles.snippet: In the wake of the last recession, government spending dried up, dragging out the recovery. Policymakers warn against letting that happen again.
articles.abstract: In the wake of the last recession, government spending dried up, dragging out the recovery. Policymakers warn against letting that happen again.
articles.lead_paragraph: Trillions of dollars in federal aid to households and businesses has allowed the U.S. economy to emerge from the first six months of the coronavirus pandemic in far better shape than many observers had feared last spring.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Jeanna Smialek
